thread.title: Harley Kirsch, Matt Laris help Eastside Catholic steamroll O’Dea, 42-14
thread.title_full: Harley Kirsch, Matt Laris help Eastside Catholic steamroll O’Dea, 42-14

author: Matt Massey
title: Harley Kirsch, Matt Laris help Eastside Catholic steamroll O’Dea, 42-14
text:
Harley Kirsch, Matt Laris help Eastside Catholic steamroll O’Dea, 42-14   11:01 pm Laris hauled in seven catches for 191 yards and two touchdowns as top-ranked Eastside Catholic withstood an early fight to subdue seventh-ranked O’Dea 42-14 on Friday night in a Metro League Mountain Division clash at ECHS. By Matt Massey Special to The Seattle Times 
SAMMAMISH — When Harley Kirsch, the Cornell-bound signal caller, fired, Matt Laris, the 6-foot-4, 215-pound receiver and Cal commit, was there. 
Laris hauled in seven catches for 191 yards and two touchdowns as top-ranked Eastside Catholic withstood an early fight to subdue seventh-ranked O’Dea 42-14 on Friday night in a Metro League Mountain Division clash at ECHS. 
“We’ve been building this connection since eighth grade and we’ve just been killin’ it, I think,” said Laris, who made a leaping grab in a crowd on a 40-yard Hail Mary touchdown pass from Kirsch with no time left in the first half for a 28-14 cushion. 
“I think we’re really at the peak of our relationship here. We’ve really been connecting in practice and in games. Most Read Stories Unlimited Digital Access. $1 for 4 weeks. 
The homecoming win moved the defending Class 3Achamps to 7-0 overall and allowed them to take the Mountain Division at 4-0. 
O’Dea, once the lone dominant team in Metro, dipped to 5-2 overall and 2-2, falling to the Crusaders for the fourth time in the last five meetings. 
“With O’Dea, the rivalry is real and it’s emotional and it’s high intensity,” EC coach Jeremy Thielbahr said. 
“When you are able to get O’Dea, and over [coach] Monte Kohler, it’s just a great victory.” 
The Crusaders get a bye next week and play in the Metro League champion on Friday, Oct. 30. 
Laris’ TD before the end of the first half gave EC a shot in the arm after the Irish closed within 21-14 on Connor Gregoire’s pinballing three-yard touchdown run with 34 seconds left before halftime. 
Kirsch finished 9-of-11 for 209 yards and three touchdowns. 
Chris Lefau crashed in from 8 yards out with 8:33 showing in the first quarter for EC and then Kirsch hit Laris down the right sideline in stride for a 71-yard TD strike with 4:32 to go in the same period to make it 14-0. 
O’Dea answered with a 21-play, 84-yard drive that consumed 11:48 capped by a 5-yard pass from Nathan West to Sam Sanchez. 
Brandon Wellington took the ensuing kickoff 85 yards down the right sideline for a touchdown and a 21-7 advantage for the Crusaders with 4:32 left in the second quarter. 
Eastside Catholic rolled into the showdown having outscored opponents by an average of 43 points per game. Matt Massey
